Modular arithmetic is a system of arithmetic for integers, where numbers "wrap around" when reaching a certain value, called the modulus.

Given an integer \(m ≥ 1\), called a modulus, two integers α and β are said to be congruent modulo \(m\), if dividing both integers by \(m\) gives the same remainder. It also means that \(m\) can divide their difference; that is, there is an integer \(k\) such that: $$ α - β = k m$$

Congruent integers can be represented like this: [α ≡ β (mod m)]. Examples: [11 ≡ 20 (mod 3)], [16 ≡ 41 (mod 5)] and [17 ≡ 57 (mod 4)].

We need to prove that \(30| n^{21} - n\). The prime factors of 30 are 2, 3 and 5. Since \((2,3)=1\), \((2,5)=1\) and \((3,5)=1\), then by proving \(2| n^{21} - n\), \(3| n^{21} - n\) and \(5| n^{21} - n\), we can prove \((2)(3)(5)| n^{21} - n\) or \(30| n^{21} - n\).

We can rewrite \(2| n^{21} - n\) as \(2| n(n^{20} - 1)\). If \(n\) is even then \((n(n^{20} - 1))\) would be divisible by 2, and if \(n\) is odd, then \(n^{20}\) would also be odd, and \((n(n^{20} - 1))\) would be divisible by 2.

We can rewrite \(3| n^{21} - n\) as \(3| n (n^{20} - 1)\). If \(n\) is divisible by 3, then \((n (n^{20} - 1)\) would also by divisible by 3. If \(n ≡ 1 \bmod 3\), then:

$$\begin{align} n^{20} &≡ 1^{20} \bmod 3 \\ n^{20} &≡ 1 \bmod 3 \\ n^{20} - 1 &≡ 0 \bmod 3 \end{align}$$

Therefore, \((n(n^{20} - 1))\) would also be divisible by 3. Now suppose \(n ≡ 2 \bmod 3\), then:

$$\begin{align} n^{20} &≡ 2^{20} \bmod 3 \\ n^{20} &≡ 2^{10} 2^{10} ≡ (1024)(1024) \bmod 3 \\ n^{20} &≡ (1)(1) ≡ 1\bmod 3 \end{align}$$

Therefore, \((n(n^{20} - 1))\) would also be divisible by 3. So \((n(n^{20} - 1))\) is divides by 3 for all \(n \in \mathbb{Z}\).

We can rewrite \(5| n^{21} - n\) as \(5| n (n^{20} - 1)\). If \(n\) is divisible by 5, then \((n (n^{20} - 1))\) would be divisible by 5. As for the other cases:

$$\begin{align} \text{if } n &≡ 1 \bmod 5 \\ n^{20} &≡ 1^{20} \bmod 5 \\ n^{20} &≡ 1 \bmod 5 \\ \text{if } n &≡ 2 \bmod 5 \\ n^{20} &≡ 2^{20} \bmod 5 \\ n^{20} &≡ 1 \bmod 5 \\ \text{if } n &≡ 3 \bmod 5 \\ n^{20} &≡ 3^{20} \bmod 5 \\ n^{20} &≡ (3^{10})(3^{10}) \bmod 5 \\ n^{20} &≡ (4)(4) ≡ 16 \bmod 5 \\ n^{20} &≡ 1 \bmod 5 \\ \text{if } n &≡ 4 \bmod 5 \\ n^{20} &≡ 4^{20} \bmod 5 \\ n^{20} &≡ (4^5)(4^5)(4^5)(4^5) \bmod 5 \\ n^{20} &≡ (4)(4)(4)(4) ≡ 256 \bmod 5 = n^{20} &≡ 1 \bmod 5 \end{align}$$

This means if \(5 \nmid n\), then \(5 | n^{20}-1\). Therefore, for all \(n\), \((n(n^{20}-1))\) would be divisible by 5.

If \((n(n^{20}-1))\) or \((n^{21}-n)\) is divisible by 2, 3 and 5, then it is divisible by 30.
